comments:
I've installed 3.1
I get this error when starting it as a 'regular' user

"An error has occurred. See the log file
/usr/local/eclipse/configuration/1120086080617.log."

There is no file by this name in this directory.
I am able to start 3.1 as root.
My old installation 3.02 still works for root and user.

Using SuSe Linux 9.2

How did you install Eclipse 3.1? Extracted it to an empty dir or on top of a
previous install? 

Please open a shell and run Eclipse as user with the given command line:

<eclipse-install>/eclipse -debug -consolelog 

And attach the resulting output to this PR. Thanks.

output from the command is below.
it shows that it can't write to /usr/local/eclipse/configuration/...
so i did this (as root):
# cd /usr/local/eclipse/configuration
# chmod +777 -R *
and it now works.

/usr/local/eclipse/configuration/1120150328846.log.>

Might be dup of bug 101892.

You should not make the install configuration directory writable. The whole
install should be write protected to any users (except root), and Eclipse should
jut work fine.

Would you be willing to trash that install location and unpack Eclipse 3.1 again
so we can investigate the problem? You would have to delete the
~/.eclipse/org.eclipse.platform_3.1.0 directory as well.

Thanks.

I now get an error:
Can't save periodic table

So i have to change permissions somewhere.
Where is this?

Please see my comment 3 above. You are not expected/supposed to change any
permissions to be able to run Eclipse.

I don't think this is an eclipse bug, in retrospect.
I installed as root, which is apparently not the thing to do.

No, that is perfectly fine. You can install as root and run as a regular user.
This is how a single Eclipse install can be shared by multiple users.

So here is how I installed (as root)

My existing 3.02 was in /usr/local/eclipse/

I copied everything under this to /usr/local/eclipse_3.02/
then i deleted everything under/usr/local/eclipse/
Having unzipped the downloaded 3.1 file in /root/, i moved the contents to
/usr/local/eclipse/.  
Then i copied plugins (cdt, photran, metrics, log4j) from
/usr/local/eclipse_3.02/plugins/ to /usr/local/eclipse/plugins/

Could you try installing Eclipse 3.1 as root again and before installing any
plug-ins, running it as regular user?

This might be a dup of bug 101892 (see bug 101892 comment 12 and following
comments). 

Mickey, what are the permissions for the Eclipse install directory
(/usr/local/eclipse)? They should be "drwxr-xr-x".

Ok, that explains it. It should be as described in comment 10 above (this is how
Eclipse is shipped). By the way you said you installed the other products
(comment 8), this is *not* a duplicate of bug 101892, just has the same effects.
You probably tweaked the permissions for the install directory manually leaving
it in an invalid state (install root has full permissions, configuration under
install has restricted permissions).

Please reopen if that does not fix your problem.

I removed eclipse and then
1. As root, installed into /usr/local/eclipse
2. Started as regular user with no problems
3. As root once again, copied plugins from old eclipse folder to new
4. Started as regular user with no problems, again

I think the mistake i made the first time was that i ran eclipse as root.  
I think this caused permissions to change such that it wouldn't work for a
regular user because that user didn't have permissions to write to certain areas.
